article.title: Generating Log-normal Mock Catalog of Galaxies in Redshift Space

multiple_choice_question.text: What can we conclude about the pairwise line-of-sight velocity PDF of dark matter halos from this figure?
choices: The PDF is always perfectly Gaussian, regardless of halo mass or separation.
The PDF has a negative mean and skewness at small separations, indicating more approaching pairs than recessing pairs due to gravity.
The PDF is unaffected by halo mass, showing identical distributions for low-mass and high-mass halos.
The mean velocity of halo pairs is always zero, even at separations of ~100h⁻¹Mpc.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure compares the real-space galaxy power spectrum measured from log-normal mock catalogs with the input power spectrum. What does the figure demonstrate?
choices: The log-normal mock generator fails to reproduce the input power spectrum.
The measured and input power spectra agree very well, particularly for k < 2 h Mpc⁻¹.
The binning effect is negligible and does not need to be accounted for when comparing the measured and predicted power spectra.
The Nyquist frequency for these measurements is irrelevant to the accuracy of the power spectrum estimation.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure compares the real-space galaxy two-point correlation function measured from log-normal mock catalogs with the input correlation function. What does the bottom panel illustrate?
choices: Large discrepancies between the measured and input correlation functions, indicating a failure of the log-normal mock generator.
The measured and input correlation functions agree very well over a wide range of scales.
The bin size used for the correlation function has no impact on the agreement between the measured and input values.
The spikes at r ≈ 120-130 h⁻¹Mpc indicate a systematic error in the measurement process.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows galaxy overdensity as a function of matter overdensity, both smoothed over different scales. What conclusion can be drawn from this figure?
choices: Galaxy overdensity is always directly proportional to matter overdensity, confirming a perfectly linear bias relation.
Smoothing scale has no impact on the relation between galaxy and matter overdensities.
The proportionality relation in power spectra between galaxy and matter does not guarantee a proportional relation between their smoothed densities.
The error on the mean galaxy overdensity is negligible and does not affect the results.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows pairwise line-of-sight velocity PDFs from log-normal mock catalogs. What does the comparison between PDFs with different linear biases (b) indicate?
choices: The pairwise line-of-sight velocity PDF is independent of galaxy bias.
Galaxies with different biases have identical velocities, rendering the bias parameter irrelevant.
Pair weighting affects the PDFs, as galaxies with high (low) bias are weighted higher (lower) density regions.
The triangles representing theoretical calculations significantly deviate from the measured PDFs.
